folder: Furman Street & Montague Street, Brooklyn, NY
text:
Furman Street, at Montague Street, showing at the left, is a part of the original James S. Rookwell place, later owned by Litchfield. The house at the right, in the hollow, used as a saloon is on the S.W. corner of Furman and Montague Streets.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Montague Street & Furman Street, Brooklyn, NY
text:
(1) Montague Street, west to Furman Street, showing from left to right, Montague Terrace and Pierrepont Place, connected by the pedestrians footbridge. At the left, is the Litchfield Mansion, at No. 1 Montague Terrace, to the right is the mansion of A.A. Low at No. 3.

1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) The same, showing a section of the Litchfield property, and to the east, the East River and a faint outline of Manhattan.

1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Montague Street & Furman Street, Brooklyn, NY
text:
(1) Montague Street, west to Furman Street, showing from left to right, Montague Terrace and Pierrepont Place, connected by the pedestrians footbridge. At the left, is the Litchfield Mansion, at No. 1 Montague Terrace, to the right is the mansion of A.A. Low at No. 3.

folder: Montague Street & Furman Street, Brooklyn, NY
text:
(1) Montague Street, west to Furman Street, showing at the right, the A.A. Low residence, No. 3 Pierrepont Place, and at the left, a section of No. 2 Montague Terrace, the Litchfield home.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) The same, showing a more inclusive view of the A.A. Low residence.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Montague Street & Furman Street, Brooklyn, NY
text:

folder: Furman Street & Montague Street, Brooklyn, NY
text:
Furman Street, west side, north from above Montague Street. A rear view of warehouses on the East River, facing Furman Street. In the background, is the Brooklyn Bridge. The Pierrepont Stores at right foreground, were first occupied in 1868.

April 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Montague Street & Furman Street, Brooklyn, NY
text:
1. Montague Street, north side, east from Furman Street. In the center background, is the Residence of Henry E. Pierrepont. April 1925.

2. The same, showing the viaduct over Montague Street, at the upper right, and the construction of Montague Street itself. April 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Furman Street & Montague Street, Brooklyn, NY
text: Furman Street, north from Montague Street. The homes on the upper level at the right, face Columbia Heights. March 11, 1929.

folder: Montague Street & Furman Street, Brooklyn, NY
text:
Montague Street, east from Furman Street.
March 1, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Montague Street & Furman Street, Brooklyn, NY
text:
Montague Street, (extreme left corner of view), west of Furman Street, showing in the foreground to the left of the Royal Netherlands and West India Mail S.S. Co's pier the New York Dock Railroad terminus which connects with 10 railroad lines. In the background across the East River is the skyline of lower Manhattan.

April 5, 1938.

P. L. Sperr
